The Program  The global crisis that intensified after September 2008 has affected the 
Rationale  Indonesian economy in four related respects: (i) the first-round effects of 
the global financial crisis had repercussions for the domestic financial 
sector, leading to significant capital flight and exchange rate depreciation 
in  the  second  half  of  2008;  (ii)  the  second-round  effects  of  global 
demand destruction have hurt the real economy, resulting in a slowdown 
in  economic  growth  from  the  fourth  quarter  (Q4)  of  2008  until  now; 
(iii) the crisis has had feedback to fiscal policy, resulting in a decline in 
tax  revenue  collection  and  a  wider  government  budget  deficit  than 
initially planned, at a time of limited access to global credit markets; and 
(iv)  the  economic  impacts  threaten  to  undo  recent  gains  in 
unemployment and poverty reduction.  
In the context of the second-round effects on the real economy and the 
emerging fiscal constraint, the Government of Indonesia has requested 
ADB to provide a countercyclical support loan of $500 million to support 
its  public  expenditure  program  for  2009.  The  request  for  financing 
stemmed from the Government’s concerns to ensure predictability in its 
budget financing, given the necessity for a temporary fiscal stimulus 
within its medium-term fiscal program. The Government projects gross 
financing requirements for 2009 at $24.5 billion, including domestic and 
external debt that matures in 2009. Net financing (after amortization) for 
2009 is projected at $13.6 billion, of which 64% will need to be raised in 
the second half of 2009. Therefore, the INO-CS will provide additional 
financing to the Government for its larger fiscal stimulus in 2009 and 
2010. This will allow the Government to stimulate an economic recovery, 
protect  its  social  spending  and  poverty  alleviation  programs,  and 
continue with its longer-term development objectives in 2009 and 2010.   
The Government’s fiscal policy response to the economic slowdown has 
been swift and broadly effective. Like most other developing economies, 
the  national  government  budget  does  not  have  automatic  stabilizers

ii 
 
embedded on the expenditure side of the budget. Therefore, with the 
economy  quickly  decelerating  in  the  fourth  quarter  of  2008,  it  was 
necessary for the Government to announce an additional countercyclical 
fiscal program in February 2009 to compensate for the fall in private 
consumption and investment and focusing on tax relief, carrying over 
2008  infrastructure  projects,  increasing  capital  spending  and 
maintenance, expanding flagship social assistance programs, and policy 
measures to speed up disbursements of critical public spending. Overall, 
the  Government's  countercyclical  fiscal  stimulus  amounts  to  about 
Rp113 trillion.  
 
ADB  staff  estimates  that  without  this  countercyclical  fiscal  stimulus 
package, economic growth would be between 2.0% and 3.0% in 2009. 
ADB  staff  estimates  also  show  that  informal  employment  and 
unemployment  could  rise  by  more  than  1.8 million  persons.  Poverty 
could also increase by about 3 million–4 million persons or about 1–2 
percentage points of the population—reversing recent gains in poverty 
reduction.  
The INO-CS is anchored by ADB’s existing Development and Policy 
Support  Program  (DPSP)  series.  Under  the  DPSP  series,  reform 
measures  relating  to  debt  and  fiscal  policy  management  have 
contributed  considerably  to  lower  levels  of  debt  to  GDP  and  a 
considerable increase in non-oil tax revenues. Rating agencies have 
also cited debt reduction and the Government’s commitment to reforms, 
including changes to the investment law, customs and tax reforms, and 
fiscal reforms—all activities supported by the DPSP—as the reason for 
recent sovereign rating upgrades. Policy actions supported under the 
investment  climate  have  led  to  significant  improvements  in  business 
start-up times, value-added tax (VAT) refund times, and establishment of 
a sounder and sustainable financial safety net. Important steps were 
also  established  to  help  lay  the  groundwork  for  improving  poverty 
targeting of basis services. As the 2005 fuel price hike made available 
more funds for social spending, the DPSP series supported building 
capacity  in  government  institutions  to  create  a  more  evaluative 
institutional  framework  that  would  improve  the  targeting  of  these 
released  funds.  Lessons  from  targeting  were  incorporated  into  the 
reactivated cash transfer program that accompanied the May 2008 fuel 
price increase.

I.  THE PROPOSAL 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed loan 
to  the  Republic  of  Indonesia  for  Countercyclical  Support.  The  development  policy  letter 
confirming  the  Government’s  commitment  to  implement  its  countercyclical  fiscal  stimulus 
program and its medium-term development program is in Appendix 1.  
 
II.  REQUEST FOR ASSISTANCE FROM THE                                            
COUNTERCYCLICAL SUPPORT FACILITY 
2.  The  proposed  loan  under  the  Countercyclical  Support  Facility  (CSF)  of  the  Asian 
Development Bank (ADB) comes at a critical time for Indonesia. 1  It is designed to maintain the 
momentum of its economic recovery and key development efforts at a challenging time of 
limited access to global financial markets and the first global recession since World War II. The 
global crisis that intensified after September 2008 has affected the Indonesian economy in four 
related respects: (i) the first-round effects of the global financial crisis had repercussions for the 
domestic financial sector, leading to significant capital flight and exchange rate depreciation in 
the second half of 2008; (ii) the second-round effects of the sharp contraction in global demand 
have hurt the real economy, resulting in a slowdown in economic growth from the fourth quarter 
(Q4) of 2008 until now; (iii) the crisis has had feedbacks to fiscal policy, resulting in a decline in 
tax revenue collection and a wider government budget deficit than initially planned, at a time of 
limited access to global credit markets; and (iv) the economic impact of the global financial crisis 
threatens to undo recent gains in unemployment reduction and poverty reduction.  
3.  Given the second-round effects on the real economy and the emerging fiscal constraint, 
the Government of Indonesia has requested ADB to provide a countercyclical support loan of 
$500 million to support its public expenditure program for the second half of 2009 and 2010. 
The  request  for  financing  stemmed  from  the  Government’s  concerns  about  ensuring 
predictability in its budget financing, given the necessity for a temporary fiscal stimulus in 2009 
and its continuation in 2010. The Government projects gross financing requirements for 2009 at 
$24.5 billion, including domestic and external debt that matures in 2009. Net financing (after 
amortization) for 2009 is projected at $13.6 billion, of which 64% will need to be raised in the 
second half of 2009 (Table 4). Therefore, the INO-CS will provide additional official financing to 
the Government for its larger fiscal stimulus in 2009 and 2010, while the costs of servicing the 
existing debt are also projected to rise. The Government has met the access criteria under the 
Countercyclical Support Facility (Appendix 2). 
4.  Adverse effects of the global financial crisis. The global financial crisis has adversely 
affected the economy. This impact is manifested in several ways. While domestic consumption 
growth remained positive in the first semester of 2009, partly supported by the Government’s 
effective fiscal stimulus, economic growth weakened to 4.0% in Q2 2009 from 4.4% in Q1, and 
is projected to weaken further in the second semester compared with 6.1% economic growth in 
2008. The contraction in exports of 27% in the first semester of 2009 and collapse in foreign 
direct investment were the key factors behind this sharper than expected economic slowdown.2 
Indonesia is also experiencing temporary fiscal stress because of the economic slowdown. Tax 
revenues declined by 6.2% in the first semester of 2009 over the same period in 2008 and non-
tax revenue (primarily natural resource revenues) declined by 33% over the same period. Debt

government budget because of higher interest rates on government debt issuances. The 2009

5.  Sound  macroeconomic  management.  The  Government  has  maintained  sound 
macroeconomic management and introduced preemptive measures to manage the increased 
downside risks to the domestic financial sector and external position. This is reflected in an 
improvement in the external balance, with gross international reserves equivalent to 6 months of 
import cover and servicing of official external debt, a low inflation environment, and a sound 
banking sector. The Government has operated a prudent fiscal policy for the last several years, 
which has resulted in a continuous decline in Indonesia’s public debt–GDP ratio from over 55% 
in 2004 to around 32% at the end of 2008. 
 
6.  Prudent fiscal response. The Government’s fiscal response to the crisis has been swift 
and  effective.  It  announced  a  countercyclical  spending  program  in  February  2009.  The 
countercyclical program focuses on (i) providing substantial tax cuts to boost household income 
and payroll tax relief to firms operating in labor-intensive industries to protect jobs, (ii) expanding 
capital  expenditure  and  carrying  over  the  2008  infrastructure  projects,  increasing  capital 
maintenance and material spending, and (iii) scaling up key social assistance programs. 
 
7.  Fiscal  space  and  debt  sustainability.  In  the  context  of  its  debt  level,  the 
countercyclical spending program is expected not to adversely affect debt sustainability as a 
large proportion of the 2009 budget stimulus is temporary in nature. A cross country comparison 
drawing on IMF publications indicates that Indonesia is well placed to sustain its debt at prudent 
levels (Appendix 9 Table A9.2). A more recent IMF country study finds that a primary surplus of 
0.3% of GDP will stabilize debt below 30% of GDP (Appendix 4).  
 
8.  Donor  coordination.  The  INO-CS  is  an  outcome  of  ADB  policy  dialogue  with  the 
Government  and  coordination  with  development  partners  under  existing  loan  programs  to 
Indonesia, and complements the Development Policy Support Program (DPSP)3 and the Public 
Expenditure Support Facility (PESF).4 The DPSP is a series of five annual, single-tranche loans 
supporting the development policy agenda of the Government as envisioned in the national 
medium-term  development  plan  (RPJM),  and  cofinanced  with  the  World  Bank  and  the 
Government of Japan. The cluster aims to help the Government achieve its medium-term 
growth and poverty reduction objectives through four core policy areas: (i) macroeconomic 
stability  and  creditworthiness  through  continued  monitoring  of  macroeconomic  indicators; 
(ii) improving the investment climate through regulatory reforms, tax and customs reforms, and 
strengthening financial sector and small and medium-sized enterprise (SME) access to finance; 
(iii) improving public financial management and governance by strengthening budgeting, internal 
control systems, transparency and procurement, and civil service reform; and (iv) improving 
delivery  of  public  services  to  the  poor  through  pro-poor  targeting  of  public  programs  and 
strengthening community-driven development.

9.  Under the DPSP series, reform measures relating to debt and fiscal policy management 
have contributed considerably to lower levels of debt to GDP and a considerable increase in 
non-oil tax revenues. Rating agencies have also cited debt reduction and the Government’s 
commitment to reforms, including changes to the investment law, customs and tax reforms, and 
fiscal reforms—all activities supported by the DPSP—as the reason for recent sovereign rating 
upgrades.  Policy  actions  supported  under  the  investment  climate  have  led  to  significant 
improvements  in  business  start-up  times,  value-added  tax  (VAT)  refund  times,  and 
establishment of a sounder and sustainable financial safety net. Important steps were also 
taken to help lay the groundwork for improving poverty targeting of basis services. As the 2005 
fuel price hike made available more funds for social spending, the DPSP series supported 
building capacity in government institutions to create a more evaluative institutional framework 
that  would  improve  the  targeting  of  these  released  funds.  Lessons  from  targeting  were 
incorporated into the reactivated cash transfer program that accompanied the May 2008 fuel 
price increase.  
 
10.  In response to global financial market failure in September 2008 and subsequently 
Indonesia’s restricted access to credit markets at that time, development partners (ADB, the 
Government of Australia, the Government of Japan, and the World Bank) approved the PESF. 
As a stand-by loan facility, its key objective is to provide insurance in the event that global 
financial markets fail again as in Q3 2008. The access conditions to the funds include an 
inability to meet specified quarterly financing targets within agreed market access conditions 
and the continued maintenance of an appropriate macroeconomic policy framework. Since then, 
global financial markets have begun to stabilize. Therefore, it is projected that the PESF funds 
will not be disbursed in 2009 as market conditions improve relative to September 2008. The 
PESF  established  a  structured  mechanism  for  crisis-related  policy  dialogue  between 
development partners and the Government. It also established a macroeconomic monitoring 
mechanism  through  which  quarterly  reports  and  meetings  between  the  Government  and 
development partners are held. This mechanism will be used to monitor the macroeconomic 
performance under the INO-CS (paras. 47–51). The formulation of the INO-CS has greatly 
benefited from this consultative and monitoring process, as it has been an invaluable vehicle for 
providing the Government with input on its countercyclical fiscal program, additional measures 
to mitigate the increased downside risks to the macro economy, and ways to strengthen poverty 
monitoring and coordination efforts (Appendix 7).   
 
III.  THE GLOBAL CRISIS AND COUNTRY CONTEXT 
 
A.  The Global Crisis and its Impact on the Indonesian Economy, Employment, and 
Poverty 
 
11.  The global economic downturn, triggered by the collapse of the US subprime mortgage 
market, has turned into one of the sharpest global economic recessions in modern history. Most 
developed economies are in deep recession in 2009, and the pace of economic growth in 
developing countries has declined significantly, and in some cases has become negative. The 
latest International Monetary Fund (IMF) projections suggest that economic growth in developed 
countries this year will contract by 3.8%. The volume of world trade is expected to fall by 12.2% 
and foreign direct investment is estimated to fall by about 30% from 2008 levels. The IMF also 
projects that the global economy will only moderately recover next year, as financial market

4   
stabilization  will  take  longer  than  previously  envisioned.  Developing  countries’  access  to 
international credit markets will remain curtailed as a consequence. 5 
 
12.  First-round effects of the global financial crisis. Spillovers from the global financial 
crisis on the Indonesian financial sector—mainly equity markets and the balance of payments—
were particularly severe in Q4 2008 and more so than in most other regional economies. Equity 
prices  fell  by  50%  and  investors  unbundled  financial  portfolios,  resulting  in  a  decline  of 
$6.5 billion in gross international reserves in Q4 and a 31% depreciation in the rupiah exchange 
rate from November 2008 to February 2009. Spillovers to the domestic banking system have 
been relatively muted because of the limited exposure to troubled US assets, and low exposure 
to securitization and off-balance sheet activities. The banking system remains sound, with a 
capital asset ratio of 17% and gross nonperforming loans at under 5% as of June 2009.    
  
13.  However, the global credit crunch that started in mid-2008 and intensified in Q4 2008 
hurt the Indonesian economy by making access to international and domestic credit markets 
more expensive for both the public and private sectors. Yields on Indonesian domestic bonds 
picked up since mid-2008 and spiked sharply in October to as high as 20%, and spreads 
on  Indonesia’s international bond surged by about 650 basis points (bps) (Figure 1e). This was 
due to a rapid increase in domestic lending of about 30%, in part attributable to the squeeze on 
US dollar lines, and capital outflow and the associated rupiah exchange rate depreciation. 
Elevated risk perceptions about the Indonesian financial sector and economy have limited 
Indonesia’s access to international credit markets and raised the cost of borrowing.  
 
14.  Second-round effects of global demand destruction. Indonesia is experiencing the 
second-round effects of the global economic downturn. Initially, it seemed the impact of the 
global downturn on Indonesia’s growth conditions was moderate. Economic growth was 5.5% in 
Q4 2008 and a respectable 4.4% in Q1 2009. The latest economic data from the Central Bureau 
of Statistics indicate that the economy is weakening, with growth at 4.0% in Q2 2009 on a year-
on-year basis. Moreover, the data show that public expenditure on goods and services has 
been  the  main  engine  of  growth  in  the  first  semester  of  2009,  followed  by  household 
consumption, benefiting from one-off election spending and tax cuts implemented as part of the 
stimulus package. Private consumption and investment growth are weakening and exports have 
severely contracted (Figure 1a). As a consequence a negative output gap (actual economic 
growth below potential growth) of between 3.0% and 4.0% has emerged in 2009 (Figure 1b). In 
January 2009, year-on-year export values had fallen about 36%. Although the rate of decline 
has slowed, export values are still down by 27% in June 2009 on a year-on-year basis. Import 
values have also contracted by 36% in the first half or 2009 because of lower commodity prices 
on resource exports, declining imports of components for the export sector and falling domestic 
demand. Inflow of remittances also declined by 15% from $1.3 billion in Q4 2008 to $1.1 billion 
in Q2 2009 suppressing incomes of poorer families reliant on remittances. ADB staff estimates 
that without the fiscal stimulus package implemented in the first half of 2009, economic growth 
would have been between 2.0% and 3.0% (Appendix 3).   
 
15.  With this background, the Government revised its macroeconomic framework in June 
2009 and now projects growth of 4.3% for 2009 with higher unemployment and poverty. The 
IMF and ADB staff project economic growth at 3–4% for 2009 because of suppressed export 
growth  and  falling  investments.  However,  because  of  lower  trade  intensity,  Indonesia’s 
vulnerability to export fluctuations is less than its neighbors. These projections translate to

16.  The  global  financial  crisis  and  economic  downturn  affects  the  Government’s  fiscal

the country’s large gross financing needs. During normal market conditions, Indonesia was able 
to  raise  a  sufficient  amount  (in  the  range  of  $12  billion–$13  billion)  from  domestic  and 
international  markets  in  2007  and  2008.  Tighter  global  liquidity  and  higher  risk  premiums 
combined  with  high  gross  financing  needs  have  raised  interest  rates  on  Indonesian  debt 
compared  with  other  economies  in  the  region.  Consequently,  debt  interest  costs  are  now 
projected to rise by an additional $1 billion in the revised 2009 budget. Second, with weakening 
economic growth, the Government needs to provide a fiscal stimulus in 2009 and 2010. Third, 
the collapse in commodity prices and a slowing economy have resulted in a decline in budget 
revenues of about 13.6% in the first semester of 2009 over the same period in 2008. Income tax 
collections have declined 4.5%, customs collection declined by 16.5%, and non-tax collection 
(including  resource  revenues)  declined  by  33%  (Figure  1f).  Tax  cuts  as  part  of  the  fiscal 
stimulus  also  contributed  to  the  decline  in  tax  revenue  collection  in  2009.  As  a  result  of 
increased spending and decline in budget revenues, the 2009 budget deficit is now projected to 
widen from the original programmed deficit of 1.0% to 2.5% of GDP, which is still relatively low 
by international standards reflecting the Government’s prudent fiscal stance. It is programming a 
budget deficit of 1.6% of GDP for 2010 to maintain the fiscal stimulus, given the projected 
further weakening of the economy.  
 
17.  Poverty  alleviation  and  employment.  The  poverty  rate  has  fallen  by  about 
1 percentage point per year since 2003, reaching 17.8% in 2006, and falling further to 14.2% in 
early 2009. However, poverty remains a serious problem in absolute terms in Indonesia with 
over 35 million people below the national poverty line and another 42% of the population 
vulnerable to falling into poverty if their circumstances suddenly deteriorate. Indicative of this 
vulnerability to poverty, the labor market has severely weakened in recent months. Figure 1d 
describes rising labor market stress in 2009. Four years of solid economic growth generated 2.7 
million formal jobs (defined as regular wage jobs) from 2005 to 2008, of which 1.6 million were 
created  in  2008.  Coinciding  with  robust  employment  growth  was  a  continuous  decline  in 
unemployment from 11.5% of the labor force in 2003 to 8.1% in 2008. According to the latest 
household labor survey carried out in February 2009, employers have significantly reduced 
hiring activity, with only about an additional 400,000 formal jobs created from February 2008 to 
February 2009. On the other hand, the informal sector continues to expand with more than an 
additional 2 million workers now engaged in informal activities (defined as casual workers, self-
employed, and unpaid family workers). The Government is concerned that the current global 
financial crisis will have adverse effects on its efforts to reduce poverty if there is a significant 
reduction in economic growth, retrenchments, and shrinking employment opportunities. Recent 
retrenchment data from the Department of Manpower and Transmigration point to increased 
layoffs, particularly in the export sector. Based on the current low growth scenario of 3–4.% 
growth  for  2009,  ADB  staff  estimates  that  only  about  half  a  million  formal  jobs  would  be 
generated and informal employment and unemployment would rise by more than 1.5 million 
persons. ADB staff estimates also show that without the fiscal stimulus informal employment 
and unemployment could have risen by more than 1.8 million persons. Poverty could have also 
increased  by  about  3  million–4 million  persons  or  about  1–2  percentage  points  of  the 
population—reversing recent gains in poverty reduction.

6   
B.   The Government's Macroeconomic Management 
 
18.  Appropriate and responsive policy. The Government’s macroeconomic policy stance 
to the increased downside risks to the economy from the global crisis has been appropriate and 
responsive. Stability is reflected in the improvement of key macroeconomic indicators. On the 
external side, earlier concerns about external risks to the balance of payments arising from 
corporate rollover and domestic resident capital outflows did not materialize. Foreign reserves 
have stabilized since November 2008 to $57.9 billion at the end of August 2009, sufficient to 
cover 6 months of imports. Conventionally, at least 3 months of import coverage is considered a 
sufficient buffer against modest shocks to the balance of payments. On the monetary side, Bank 
Indonesia has broadly operated an appropriate monetary policy stance throughout the crisis. In 
early 2008, it raised interest rates to counter the threat of second-round inflationary pressures 
arising from the surge in global commodity prices. It then shifted to an expansionary monetary 
position at the end of 2008 to provide sufficient liquidity to the banking system against the 
backdrop of rapidly falling inflation. Inflation fell to 2.7% (year-on-year) in July 2009, from its 
peak of 12.1% in August 2008. Inflation is expected to remain benign for the rest of this year, 
indicative of the slump in domestic economic activity and lower commodity prices.  
 
19.  The Government’s response to mitigating the risk of the global financial crisis on the 
Indonesian  economy  was  swift  and  involves  a  number  of  proactive  measures  aimed  at 
reassuring confidence in the domestic financial sector, increasing liquidity in the banking system, 
and strengthening Bank Indonesia’s lender of last resort facility. To maintain the confidence and 
stability of the financial system, the Government (i) issued a financial safety net regulation that 
clearly  establishes  the  roles,  responsibilities,  and  procedures  that  govern  the  actions  and 
responses of Bank Indonesia, the minister of finance, and the Deposit Insurance Corporation in 
the event of the failure of a financial institution; (ii) strengthened the role of Bank Indonesia’s 
lender of last resort facility by allowing banks to borrow in the short term from the central bank, 
backed up by high quality assets such as government bonds and Bank Indonesia Certificate; 
(iii) increased coverage of the deposit insurance scheme; and (iv) eased liquidity in the banking 
sector through monetary expansion. Policy measures on the latter include gradually cutting 
Bank Indonesia policy rates from 9.5% in December 2008 to 6.5% by August 2009, injecting 
rupiah  liquidity  through  repurchase  agreements,  and  reducing  the  reserve  requirement  for 
foreign currency deposits. With these proactive measures in place, indicators show signs of 
improvement. Bank liquidity eased at the end of 2008, and growth in bank lending started to 
pick up to about 16% in the first semester of 2009 on a year-on-year basis; the stock market 
and the rupiah exchange rate recovered ground since December 2008; and yields on short-term 
domestic bonds have declined, although yields on medium- and longer-term bonds remain 
elevated indicating a steeper yield curve compared to prior the global financial crisis.  
 
20.  To strengthen the external position, the Government arranged multilateral and bilateral 
swap arrangements to gain ability to call for more foreign reserves when needed. For example, 
Indonesia has access to a $14.6 billion swap facility with the People’s Republic of China. In this 
context of slowing exports and waning market confidence, Bank Indonesia has activated its 
rediscount window for trade receivables and the Government has established an export–import 
financing agency that would provide different trade finance products, including export credit 
guarantees, as well as a mandate to support diversification of export markets and SMEs’ access 
to trade finance.

21.  Fiscal situation. With the sharp fall in global demand in Q4 2008 and the spillovers of

IV.  THE GOVERNMENT’S COUNTERCYCLICAL FISCAL STIMULUS PROGRAM 
  
24.  The Government’s fiscal policy response to the economic slowdown has been swift and 
broadly effective. Like most other developing economies, the national government budget does 
not have automatic stabilizers embedded on the expenditure side of the budget. Empirical 
evidence for Indonesia suggests that only two budget items have historically exhibited a relation 
with the economic cycle—government purchases of goods and services, and debt servicing—
and the former has exhibited a distinct pro-cyclical response.6 Debt servicing costs have been 
countercyclical  because  of  the  non-discretionary  nature  of  debt  service.  Government  bond 
premiums tend to rise during economic downturns along with currency depreciation. On the 
revenue side, there appear to be modest automatic stabilizers, i.e., tax revenues and non-tax 
revenues fall during downturns. Therefore, with the economy quickly decelerating in Q4 2008, it 
was necessary for the Government to announce a national budget in February 2009 that was 
countercyclical  focusing  on  increasing  priority  capital  spending  and  carrying  over  some 
infrastructure projects from 2008, substantially increasing the materials and capital maintenance 
budget, expanding flagship social assistance programs, and providing tax relief to businesses 
and  households.  The  Government  also  announced  additional  stimulus  spending  on 
infrastructure and maintenance in July 2009 as part of its fiscal stimulus efforts. Overall, the 
countercyclical  component  of  the  budget  is  estimated  at  Rp113  trillion.  To  enhance  the 
effectiveness of the countercyclical spending program the Government also introduced policy 
measures to speed up disbursements of critical public spending.  
 
25.  The  Government  intends  to  undertake  a  second-round  fiscal  stimulus  in  the  2010 
national government budget focusing on infrastructure spending. The INO-CS will support the 
Government’s infrastructure investments included in the revised 2009 budget and the 2010 
budget aimed at improving the welfare of targeted groups in the social sector, and especially

immediate impact on stimulating household consumption as infrastructure spending is only 
expected to have an impact in the second semester of 2009 and 2010 because of the longer 
time involved in the procurement and disbursement process. The countercyclical fiscal stimulus 
package announced in February 2009 was incremental to additional countercyclical spending 
that has been incorporated into the 2009 budget.  The Government more than doubled capital 
maintenance  spending  and  increased  material  spending  in  the  order  of  Rp25  trillion  with

29.  Infrastructure.  The  Government  has  announced  a  series  of  infrastructure  projects 
specifically to support its fiscal stimulus efforts in 2009 and 2010 with a strong development 
focus (Table 3), in addition to capital spending already in the pipeline for the 2009 budget. 
These include projects already in the investment pipeline but with procurement advanced by 12 
months ahead to have an impact in the second semester of 2009 and 2010. Other infrastructure 
projects  are  new  and  designed  for  the  fiscal  stimulus  as  quick-disbursing,  labor-intensive 
projects. The projects are also selected to have a social welfare impact (such as housing for 
poor families in remote coastal fishing villages) and are designed to enhance competitiveness in 
selected  sectors  especially  agriculture  and  downstream  sectors  such  as  the  traditional 
distribution  sector  and  SMEs  operating  in  these  sectors.  These  include  enhancing  rural 
productivity projects (construction and rehabilitation of feeder roads and irrigation in rural areas); 
enhancing  competitiveness  in  the  traditional  distribution  system  (construction  of  traditional 
markets  and  SME  support);  and  economy-wide  competitiveness  enhancing  projects 
(construction of national infrastructure). As noted above, the Government also doubled capital 
maintenance spending in 2009 which are quick-disbursing, labor-intensive activities including 
national road reparation, repairs to school buildings, health facilities etc. These competitiveness 
enhancing infrastructure and SME programs will continue in the 2010 budget.     
 
30.  Social  assistance  programs.  The  Government  has  scaled  up  its  flagship  social 
assistance programs as part of its longer term reform program and also to mitigate the poverty 
impacts of the economic slowdown. In recent years, the Government has introduced better 
targeted social assistance programs in response to lessons learned from the 1998 economic 
crisis  where  the  absence  of  effective  social  assistance  programs  resulted  in  substantial 
increases in poverty. The new programs include the unconditional cash transfer (UCT) program 
first introduced in 2005 and its offspring program the conditional cash transfer (CCT) program 
currently  under  pilot  testing.  The  community-based  development  program  in  rural  areas 
(Kecamatan Development Program) and in urban areas (Urban Poverty Project) were pilot 
tested  after  the  1998  crisis,  and  recently  rolled  out  on  a  national  level  as  the  National 
Community Empowerment Program Mandiri (PNPM). Under the PNPM, the central Government 
provides  block  grants  to  communities  for  community-based  development  projects  in 
infrastructure, social and productive economy. 
 
31.  Cash transfer programs. In 2008, the Government reactivated the UCT program to 
compensate poor households for the surge in commodity and food prices. The UCT program 
covered 18.5 million households based on the database used in the previous UCT in 2005 and 
2006. Each household received Rp100,000 per month on a quarterly basis. Available data 
about the antipoverty effectiveness of the UCT are encouraging. According to data from the 
2008 National Socioeconomic Survey (SUSENAS), the UCT maintained the welfare levels of 
60% of recipient households and assisted 30% of recipient households to escape from poverty, 
while about 10% of households under the scheme fell into poverty because of food price 
inflation in 2008. The Government had extended the UCT program for 2 months in 2009

15
    
covering 18.5 million households. It was suspended in the lead-up to the national legislative 
elections in May 2009 and the presidential elections in July 2009. The CCT program is in pilot 
stage and covers about 720,000 households in 13 provinces. Families receive Rp100,000 per 
month conditional on meeting achievements on selected child education and health targets. The 
Government intends to use some of the proceeds of the INO CS loan to enhance the CCT 
program in 2010. 
 
32.  Other programs. The Government has allocated a total of Rp10.4 trillion for the PNPM 
for  2009,  of  which  Rp0.7  trillion  was  added  as  part  of  the  fiscal  stimulus  package.  The 
Operational Aid to School Program (BOS) is the largest program and provides block grants to 
needy  elementary  schools.  In  addition,  the  Government  provides  for  payment  of  health 
insurance premiums for the poor under the Government's new social health insurance scheme. 
These programs have advantageously placed the Government to channel resources to the poor 
in a timely and transparent manner, and thereby mitigate the worst effects of the economic 
downturn and external shocks on the poor. 
 
33.  These social assistance programs are the pillars of the new poverty reduction framework 
introduced in response to the current global crisis. In March 2009, the Government issued a 
presidential regulation on coordination of national poverty reduction efforts. The decree helps 
coordinate and streamline the implementation of poverty reduction efforts at national and local 
levels. The decree outlines the functions, responsibilities, and organization of the coordination 
committees for poverty reduction at national, provincial, and district levels. At the national level, 
the  coordination  committee  is  led  by  the  coordinating  minister  for  social  welfare,  with 
membership from all ministries. At the provincial level, the committee is chaired by the provincial 
governor and at district level by the district mayor or regent. The committees will have three 
program clusters focusing on social safety net programs, community empowerment programs, 
and  microcredit  and  small  business  development.  With  the  decree,  the  Government  will 
harmonize and streamline interventions from some 60 community-based projects executed by 
22 sectoral ministries. This will enable the Government to respond more efficiently to poverty 
impacts  from  the  global  financial  crisis.  Supporting  the  framework,  the  Government  is 
establishing a poverty monitoring mechanism designed to provide a timely assessment of the 
poverty impact of the current global financial crisis to stakeholders. 
 
34.  Subsidies. The central government budget still contains sizeable subsidies intended to 
protect the welfare of the poor (such as subsidies applied to rice, gasoline, kerosene, and 
electricity, among others) amounting to 14% of the central government budget in 2009. However, 
these subsidies are poorly targeted and with leakages and the overall results in terms of net 
welfare to intended recipient groups are mixed. While the Government has cut the share of 
subsidies in the budget by half from 5.6% of GDP in 2008 to 2.9% of GDP in the revised 2009 
budget,  there  is  still  substantial  room  to  cut  them  back  further  and  allocate  savings  to 
discretionary  countercyclical  spending  in  social  assistance  programs  and  infrastructure. 
Recognizing the need to contain these subsidies, the Government is finalizing its regulatory 
framework for determining and allocating subsidies within the central government budget.   
 
35.  Strengthening public financial management. The effectiveness of the Government’s 
fiscal  stimulus  package  depends  on  better  budget  execution.  The  key  spending  agencies 
(Ministries  of  Education,  Health,  Public  Works,  Communication  and  Transportation)  have 
relatively low absorptive capacity rates, causing delays in disbursements and procurement that 
could  undermine  the  Government’s  stimulus  package,  especially  with  its  record  of  under-
execution (especially in capital spending) and back-loaded spending toward the end of the year. 
For  example,  only  about  19%  of  programmed  capital  spending  was  disbursed  in  the  first

16  
5 months of 2008. To address the low disbursement rates in the first semester of the fiscal year, 
MOF  implemented  a  series  of  measures  at  the  end  of  2008  aimed  at  accelerating  the 
procurement process and utilization of savings from the 2008 budget outturn. These measures 
included (i) implementing a campaign to promote advance procurement processing, appoint 
multiyear treasury officers, and speed up disbursements through the Treasury; (ii) establishing a 
monitoring committee for the budget activity list 2009 to improve budget disbursements; (iii) 
improving the recording and reporting system in budget spending units; and (iv) issuing a series 
of circulars with simplified mechanisms and processes for carryover of unspent 2008 budget. 
These measures have improved the disbursement rates of government expenditure, especially 
current and social assistance. The measures provided a modest improvement in disbursement 
rates of capital spending in the first semester of 2009. The overall disbursement rate of line 
ministries and agencies in the first semester of 2009 was 35.8% of the total 2009 budget, up 
from 28.5% in 2008 and 28.1% in 2007.  
 
36.  Under  the  public  financial  management  reforms,  the  Government  is  introducing 
measures aimed at addressing problems with leakages and corruption with programs. This is a 
long-term effort that is also shaped by the regional autonomy implemented since 2001. These 
measures include (i) developing a medium-term expenditure framework supplemented with a 
fiscal  policy  framework;  (ii)  program  and  performance  budgeting;  and  (iii)  modernizing  the 
treasury system, including the establishment of a consolidated Treasury Single Account, and a 
financial management information system. Other supporting measures include unification of the 
planning and budgeting processes, a revised chart of accounts and budget classification, new 
treasury processes, and improved internal and external auditing. In addition, the Independent 
Anticorruption Commission (KPK) has been making substantial progress in investigating and 
prosecuting  senior  government  officials  involved  in  corrupt  practices  and  this  has  helped 
improve Indonesia’s global rankings in control of corruption.8 The oversight body has improved 
implementation of the Government's PNPM Mandiri program.  
 
V.  ECONOMIC IMPACT OF THE COUNTERCYCLICAL PROGRAM 
 
37.  The economic stimulus effects. The fiscal stimulus package is projected at 1.4% of 
GDP, covering about half of the estimated output gap for 2009 (negative output gap estimated 
at about 3.0%–4.0% before the stimulus). On this basis, the stimulus appears to be of an 
appropriate size. ADB assessment indicates that the fiscal multiplier of the package could be 
1.5%–1.6% of GDP, depending on the type of fiscal stimulus, their multiplier effects, and their 
timing (Appendix 3). For example, the total tax breaks of Rp56 trillion are likely to expand GDP 
by  less  than  this  amount  as  some  proportion  will  be  saved,  while  the  labor-intensive 
infrastructure and social assistance spending of Rp57 trillion is likely to stimulate the economy 
by up to Rp68 trillion (assuming a multiplier of 1.2). The tax cuts, social assistance programs 
(especially the UCT) and the boost in capital maintenance spending have had an immediate 
impact on household consumption. Some of the larger infrastructure projects, however, will take 
up to 12 months to have an impact because of the longer procurement and disbursement period. 
ADB staff estimates that, without the stimulus package, economic growth for 2009 would be 
between 2.0%–3.0%.

38.  Poverty impacts. An economic slowdown from 6% in 2008 to a projected 3.0%–4.0% in 
2009 will reduce the growth in per capita incomes from about 4.5% in 2008 to 1.5%–2.5% in 
2009. Based on experience with similar low growth rates, such as in 2001 to 2004, poverty is 
likely to increase in the short term. Over the medium term, a slow economic recovery will create 
persistently higher unemployment and suppressed earnings in the informal sector as new labor 
market entrants outnumber new jobs created. The Government’s fiscal stimulus through quick-
disbursing labor-intensive programs will and has partially offset the unemployment and poverty 
impacts of the crisis. However, an economic growth rate of about 6% per annum in 2011 is 
necessary to ensure a sustained reduction in unemployment and poverty (Appendix 3).  
 
VI.  OBJECTIVES, SCOPE, AND COVERAGE OF THE LOAN 
39.  The Government has requested a loan of $500,000,000 under the CSF from ADB’s 
ordinary capital resources, with interest to be determined in accordance with ADB’s London 
interbank offered rate (LIBOR)-based lending facility plus 200 bps; a 5-year term, including a 
grace period of 3 years; commitment charge of 75 bps on the undisbursed loan balance; and 
such other terms and conditions as are substantially in accordance with those set forth in the 
draft loan agreement presented to the Board. The Government has provided ADB with (i) the 
reasons for its decision to borrow under ADB’s LIBOR-based lending facility based on these 
terms and conditions, and (ii) an undertaking that these choices were its own independent 
decision and not made in reliance on any communication or advice from ADB. 
 
40.  The gross financing needs of the Government have increased from $18.2 billion in 2008 
to $24.5 billion in 2009 based on the revised 2009 budget. These growing financing needs 
reflect increased levels of domestic and foreign debt principal repayments, and changes to the 
2009 budget. The revised 2009 budget projects a lower increase in revenues because of the 
economic slowdown, and the need for additional spending to stimulate the economy in 2009 
and  for  poverty  alleviation  programs.  Overall,  the  Government  is  budgeting  for  additional 
spending and countercyclical spending up to Rp113 trillion in 2009. The Government plans to 
meet the financing needs from the following sources: (i) $13.8 billion from issuance of domestic 
and international bond issuance in the markets, (ii) $5.4 billion from the banking system and 
excess financing from 2008, and (iii) $6.6 billion from the Official Development Assistance 
program and project lending (excluding the PESF). The Government will draw down the PESF 
and related support from other development partners when it cannot meet its financing targets 
from  the  markets  within  specified  market  access  conditions  specified  in  the  Government’s 
financing plan and other conditions set out in the PESF loan agreement.

A.  Economic Contraction  
 
1.  The economy began to slow in the fourth quarter (Q4) of 2008 and growth decelerated to 
4% in Q2 2009 on a year-on-year basis, compared to a 6% growth rate in 2008. The slowdown 
in growth was broad-based, with most major economic sectors declining, driven by the export-
oriented manufacturing sector. Depressed external demand for goods and sluggish foreign 
direct investment inflows were the primary drivers behind the economic deceleration in Q2 2009. 
On the expenditure side, private consumption growth remained positive in the first semester of 
2009—partly supported by the one-off election spending in Q1 and the tax cuts as part of the 
Government’s  fiscal  stimulus  package—but  consumption  began  to  weaken  in  Q2.  Public 
expenditure was a key engine of growth in the first semester of 2009, growing by 18% over the 
same period in 2008, up from an average growth rate of 3–4% in first semesters of 2006 and 
2007, indicative of the large magnitude of the Government’s spending program in 2009 (Figure 
A3a). 
 
2.  Another way of looking at economic performance is the output gap, which measures the 
difference between potential output and actual output in terms of gross domestic product (GDP) 
growth. A small output gap suggests that the economy is at its long-run trend or full employment. 
If growth exceeds the potential growth rate (i.e., a positive output gap), it suggests the economy 
risks overheating associated with above-trend inflation. If actual growth is below potential (i.e., a 
negative output gap), this suggests an economic downturn usually associated with below-trend 
inflation. Asian Development Bank (ADB) staff estimates indicate that Indonesia’s potential 
economic growth is 6.0%–6.5% per annum. Staff estimates also indicate the emergence of a 
significant output gap in 2009, projected at 3–4% (in the absence of the fiscal stimulus), similar 
in magnitude to the one that emerged in the late 1980s (Figure A3b). Inflation is subdued, 
indicative of weakening aggregate demand and the fall in commodity prices (Figure A3c).  
 
B.   Impact of the Government’s Countercyclical Public Spending Program   
 
3.  Economic  stimulus  effects. In times of a negative output gap, governments  may 
stimulate the economy through a combination of policy instruments such as (i) expansionary 
monetary policy and therefore lowering interest rates to stimulate investment and consumption, 
and (ii) fiscal expansion through tax cuts and increasing discretionary public spending. An 
appropriate fiscal expansion will depend on its size relative to the output gap and the multiplier 
(or second-round effects) of the different components of the fiscal stimulus. Empirical evidence 
for  other  countries  indicates  that  infrastructure  spending  has  the  largest  multiplier  effects, 
followed  by  cash  transfers  to  poor  families;  tax  breaks  have  the  lowest  multiplier  effects 
(generally less than 1) as some proportion will be saved. 
 
4.  The Government is using both instruments to stimulate the economy. In aggregate, the 
national government budget deficit is projected at 2.5% of GDP or an expansion of 2.4% over 
2008 (budget deficit of 0.1% in 2008). Overall, the fiscal stimulus component (incremental 
revenue and spending measures) amounts to about 1.4% of GDP to support domestic demand.

permanent  increase  in  the  taxable  income  threshold  to  Rp15.8  million  and  a  reduction  in

IN THE BASELINE SCENARIO 
 
A.  Public Debt 
 
1.  Public sector debt has declined as a share of gross domestic product (GDP) since 
2000.1 The ratio fell to a post-crisis record-low level of 33% in 2008 (Figure A4.1) owing to 
prudent fiscal management, which led to fiscal surpluses averaging almost 2% of GDP per year 
in the last decade. Reduced risk premiums, lower interest rates, and high real GDP growth also 
contributed to debt consolidation. Foreign-currency debt (mostly to multilateral institutions) has 
fallen markedly to about half of total debt, as the improved fiscal position facilitated government 
access to the domestic capital market.  
 
2.  In  the  baseline  scenario,  a  moderate  further decline in public sector  debt  is  likely. 
Despite a larger fiscal deficit, public debt is projected to fall to about 31% of GDP in 2009, 
reflecting rupiah appreciation and falling interest rates. In the medium term, the public debt–
GDP ratio is expected to decline gradually to 28.5% by 2014. Strong growth from 2011 and 
sustained fiscal prudence drive this result. A return to positive primary balances from 2011 is 
consistent with accommodating extra resources for development spending. 
 
3.  Standard stress tests suggest that the projected decline in the debt ratio could be 
vulnerable to contingent liabilities, sharp exchange rate movements, and higher interest rates 
(Figure A4.1). Fiscal contingent liabilities amounting to 10% of GDP could raise the public sector 
debt to almost 38% of GDP by 2014, with the ratio above 40% in 2010 (a level not seen since 
2005). A 30% currency depreciation would raise the debt ratio by 9 percentage points compared 
to the baseline. A large increase in real interest rates would have smaller, but still sizeable, 
effects, with the debt ratio reaching 33% by 2014. Other macroeconomic shocks have a more 
limited impact.  
 
B.  External Debt 
 
4.  Indonesia’s external debt has also declined steadily since the crisis, from over 150% of 
GDP in 1998 to 29% in 2008 (Figure A4.2). External debt as a percentage of exports has also 
declined, from 288% to 97%, over the same period. 
 
5.  In the baseline scenario, the external debt dynamics are projected to be sustainable. 
The debt–GDP ratio is projected to decline to around 22% by 2014. The main driving factors are 
(i) the projected increase in real GDP growth to 5%−6% over the medium term; (ii) a projected 
positive  growth-interest  rate  differential;  and  (iii) an  expected  increase  in  non-debt-creating 
capital inflows. The favorable trend in external debt may be reversed if these expected positive 
developments do not occur. 
 
6.  The external debt ratio is most vulnerable to shocks to the exchange rate. A one-time 
30% real exchange rate depreciation would raise the debt ratio by 14 percentage points in 2010, 
with the impact falling to 12 percentage points over the baseline by 2014.

I.  POVERTY ANALYSIS AND STRATEGY 
A. Linkages to the National Poverty Reduction Strategy and Country Partnership Strategy  
 
Indonesia’s National Poverty Reduction Strategy (NPRS) has five basic strategies for poverty reduction: (i) broadening 
opportunities,  (ii)  empowering  community  institutions,  (iii)  increasing  capacity,  (iv)  providing  social  protection,  and 
(v) promoting global partnerships. The NPRS is to be implemented through macroeconomic strategy and policies for fulfilling 
basic rights, promoting gender justice and equality, and regional development. It considers macroeconomic policies as the 
foundation for reducing poverty through a supportive business environment and broad opportunities for increasing the 
capability of the poor through four related objectives: (i) create macroeconomic stability, (ii) promote economic growth, 
(iii) increase  opportunities  for  employment  and  entrepreneurship,  and  (iv)  reduce  inequalities  between  regions.  The 
Government’s medium-term national development plan (RPJM) includes the main tenets of the previous draft NPRS and 
incorporates the eight Millennium Development Goals (MDGs). This provides an overarching framework that places human 
development and poverty reduction at the center of the development agenda. 
 
The country poverty assessmenta and country poverty partnership agreementb consider macroeconomic stability as a 
fundamental underpinning to poverty reduction. The poverty agreement also calls for expanding and improving such key basic 
services as health, education, water supply, and sanitation through public–private partnerships; and points out the need to 
expand the system of social protection. The Countercyclical Support Facility (CSF) provides support to government measures 
aimed at mitigating the impact of the global financial crisis and keeping the country on track to meet MDG targets. 
 
B.  Poverty Analysis                                                                  Targeting Classification:  General intervention 
1. Key Issues  
 
The current global financial crisis is expected to lead to reduced economic growth, retrenchments, move to informal sectors, 
and decreased real wages and living standards for a significant portion of the population. The economy is slowing down in 
2009, with growth projections ranging from 3.0% to 4%. Exports in June declined by 27% on a year-on-year basis, suggesting 
that the lower end of projections is an increasingly likely outcome for 2009. ADB staff estimates that without the fiscal 
stimulus, poverty could rise by 3 to 4 million person or 1 to 2 percentage points of the population.  
 
2. Design Features  
 
Indonesia Countercyclical Support (INO-CS) supports government efforts to mitigate the effects of the crisis by supporting a 
stimulus package, cash transfer programs for the poor, and maintaining critical spending on social sectors and infrastructure. 
 
C. Poverty Impact Analysis for Policy-Based Lending  
 
The recent fall in inflation and thus food prices has benefited the poor, which spend a larger proportion of their budget on food 
than the average household. The poverty rate declined to 14.2% in early 2009 from 14.4% in early 2008, showing the effects 
of the good rice harvest, stability in food and fuel prices, and the impact of the unconditional cash transfer (UCT) program to 
the poor and near poor that was implemented in 2008–2009. The country defines poverty based on a consumption bundle 
that consists of food items (to satisfy 2,100 calories) and basic non-food items determined by the pattern of consumption of 
reference households near the poverty line. As in most developing economies, poverty is mostly a rural phenomenon in 
Indonesia.  
 
The unemployment rate decreased to 8.14% in February 2009 from 8.46% in February 2008.However, stress in the labor 
market is showing up in a surge in people entering the informal sector in 2009, with new hire in the formal sector declining to 
400.000 from about 1.8 million in 2008. Public services also remain inadequate in Indonesia from a middle-income country 
standard. High malnutrition and maternal mortality rates, inadequate access to safe water and sanitation, and poor education 
outcomes are other dimensions of poverty. Access to rural infrastructure is also limited. Inequality has increased over time

A.  Development Policy Support Program Cluster 
 
1.  The Development Policy Support Program (DPSP)1 supports the development policy 
agenda  of  the  Development  Policy  Loan  (DPL)  series  prepared  by  a  joint  team  of  the 
Government of Indonesia, Asian Development Bank (ADB), Government of Japan, and the 
World  Bank.  The  DPL  is  a  series  of  five  annual,  single-tranche  loans  supporting  the 
development policy agenda of the Government of Indonesia, as envisioned in the national 
medium term development plan (RPJM). The cluster aims to help the Government achieve its 
medium-term  growth  and  poverty  reduction  objectives  through  four  core  policy  areas: 
(i) macroeconomic  stability  and  creditworthiness  through  continued  monitoring  of 
macroeconomic indicators; (ii) improving the investment climate through regulatory reforms, tax 
and  customs  reforms,  and  strengthening  financial  sector  and  small  and  medium-sized 
enterprises’  (SMEs’)  access  to  finance;  (iii)  improving  public  financial  management  and 
governance  by  strengthening  budgeting,  controls,  transparency  and  procurement,  and  civil 
service reform; and (iv) improving delivery of public services to the poor through pro-poor 
targeting of public programs and strengthening community-driven development.  
 
2.  Support for the RPJM through parallel cofinancing of the DPSP series is a key pillar of 
ADB’s country strategy and program 2006–2009.2 Under the country strategy and program, a 
dual-track approach is adopted to ensure that the high-level macroeconomic and governance 
reforms  supported  through  the  policy  dialogue  of  the  DPSP  series  complement,  and  are 
reinforced by, ADB’s sector programs. The approach involves structuring ADB support through 
(i) participation in the DPSP to strengthen the macroeconomic and fiscal framework while 
addressing crosscutting concerns; and (ii) sector-specific policy interventions in the areas of 
infrastructure,  financial  deepening,  local  government  finance,  and  poverty  reduction  and 
accelerated progress toward the Millennium Development Goals (MDGs). ADB’s dual-track 
approach aims to harmonize and align development partner strategies with Indonesia’s country 
strategy and priorities. Moreover, development partner harmonization around the Government’s 
own programs has bolstered country ownership of the reform process.  
 
3.  Key  features.  At  its  inception  in  2004,  the  DPL  series  was  designed  to  support 
Indonesia’s  transition  from  postcrisis  stabilization  to  more  long-term  development.  It  was 
expected to provide the foundation for continued, medium-term policy engagement in the areas 
of  macroeconomic  stability,  the  investment  climate,  and  public  financial  management  and 
anticorruption. It also provided for a flexible means of taking into account the pace and direction 
of the reforms. Hence, as the program has evolved, the scope of the reform agenda has 
become broader. The broadening of the agenda has also been accompanied by deepening of

financial management and governance. The theme of the DPL-2/DPSP-1 progressed toward 
creating fiscal space. This led to themes more focused on implementation. The emphasis of the

creating a more transparent, systematic, and coherent framework for pay and allowances based 
on a comprehensive job evaluation and pay grading. Building on this, the Ministry of Finance 
has developed a comprehensive civil service reform action plan, which is being pilot tested in 
other agencies. Important steps were also established to help lay the groundwork for improving 
poverty targeting of basis services. As the 2005 fuel price hike made available more funds for 
social spending, the DPL/DPSP supported building capacity in government institutions to create 
a more evaluative institutional framework that would improve the targeting of these released 
funds.  Lessons  from  targeting  were  incorporated  into  the  new  cash  transfer  program  that 
accompanied the May 2008 fuel price increase. The DPSP/DPL also supported critical actions 
to improve the quality of public service delivery in education and community-based development. 
 
B.  Public Expenditure Support Facility  
 
6.  The Public Expenditure Support Facility (PESF)3 is part of a joint effort of the World 
Bank, ADB, Government of Australia, and Government of Japan to support a common crisis-
mitigating action agenda with the Government of Indonesia, and provide contingent budget

financing in the event of further instability in credit markets that may result in a shortfall in 
budget financing needs. The PESF complements the World Bank’s DPL and ADB’s DPSP 
series, which reflect the Government of Indonesia’s commitment to reforms over the medium 
term. 
 
7.  Under the PESF, the Government will implement a series of confidence-boosting policy 
measures aimed at sending a strong positive signal to the markets, making it more likely that 
Indonesia will meet its commercial market borrowing targets for 2009. These policy measures 
address the increased short-term vulnerabilities and risks to the Indonesian economy from the 
global financial crisis and sharp slowdown in the global economy, and underpin the key priorities 
of the Government’s reform agenda. These measures include actions to (i) reassure financial 
markets and maintain financial system stability, (ii) sustain critical public expenditures while 
maintaining budget discipline to mitigate the poverty impacts of the growth slowdown, and 
(iii) crowd in private investment and support exports.  
 
8.  Key features of the PESF include (i) a single tranche loan with scheduled and multiple 
withdrawals;  (ii)  a  small  number  of  high-impact  policy  measures  designed  to  address  the 
adverse impacts of the ongoing financial crisis completed prior to consideration by ADB’s Board 
of Directors; (iii) a financing plan for the Government’s projected gross financing needs for 2009, 
including  projected  commercial  borrowings  in  the  domestic  and  international  markets;  and 
(iv) withdrawals  of  the  loan  amount  to  be  made  when  the  drawdown  triggers  set  in  the 
Government’s financing plan are met and the policy measures introduced under the Program 
continue to remain in place. In this way, the PESF program mirrors features of the World Bank’s 
PESF parallel cofinancing loan of a development policy loan with a deferred drawdown option 
whereby subsequent withdrawals of the single tranche loan are contingent on the drawdown 
triggers set out in the financing plan being met. Under the best case scenario, where the 
Government meets all of its financing targets from market sources, in which the global financial 
conditions do not deteriorate substantially, and approval of the PESF sends a strong positive 
market signal, no withdrawal would be expected under the PESF. Under a second scenario, in 
which the market condition remains tight and the drawdown triggers set out in the financing plan 
are met, the Government can exercise its options to access the PESF funds. Under a third 
scenario,  in  which  there  is  a  sharp  deterioration  in  the  global  financial  market  creating 
macroeconomic  instability  and/or  a  balance-of-payments  crisis,  the  PESF  is  unlikely  to  be 
effective and Indonesia will need crisis mitigation support. 
 
9.  The Government has indicated that its first preference is to use its access to domestic 
and/or  international  markets  to  meet  its  financing  targets.  The  financing  plan  incorporates 
quarterly  targets  for  rupiah  and  US  dollar  bond  issuances.  Under  the  financing  plan,  the 
Government has projected financing requirements from the market of $12.5 billion equivalent for 
2009. However, in the event of tight market conditions, the Government and development 
partners  have  established  broad  parameters  on  the  basis  of  which  the  Government  may 
withdraw the $5.5 billion funds available from the PESF to meet its quarterly financing shortfall 
during  the  program  period.  The  Government  and  development  partners  will  assess  the 
Government’s financing shortfall every quarter and determine if disbursement from the PESF is 
required.  
 
10.  In  line  with  the  financing  plan,  the  Government  and  development  partners  have 
committed to the principles that the loan would be used only in the following circumstances: 
 
(i)  Sound  macroeconomic  framework.  The  overall  macroeconomic  situation 
continues to be sound and the policy program on track. However, given the

the development partners and the Government have decided that a review of the 
Government’s macroeconomic policy framework and its progress in carrying out 
the PESF (including its financing plan) will be undertaken on a quarterly basis in

(ii)  Limited market access. Indonesia has limited market access because of global

from a set of objective criteria.    
(iii)  Phased withdrawals. Withdrawals from the PESF are phased as needed. The 
full  amount  of  the  loan  is  unlikely  to  be  required  at  once.  Therefore,  the 
Government has articulated a schedule of withdrawals in line with its financing 
plan. It is expected that the loan will be withdrawn each quarter after the joint 
government  and  development  partner  review  meeting,  with  a  cap  on  the 
maximum amount that can be drawn down each quarter.  
(iv)  Proportionate disbursement from development partners. The financing plan 
indicates that if the withdrawal is warranted, the Government will draw down 
support from development partners proportional to their commitment. This way, 
the support and risk would be spread across all the partners participating in the 
PESF.  
 
11.  The financing plan includes a governance arrangement that allows the Government and 
its development partners, including ADB, to meet in the quarterly meetings or extraordinary 
meetings  to  (i)  assess  the  Government’s  macroeconomic  policy  framework,  (ii)  evaluate 
progress  in  implementation  of  the  financing  plan,  and  (iii)  determine  the  amount  that  the 
Government  will  draw  on  support  provided  by  ADB  and  other  development  partners.  The 
Government and any development partner could also request additional meetings to respond to 
evolving economic conditions. In the event that the Government proposes changes to the 
financing plan, but the changes do not involve a change to the objective of the financing plan 
(such as changes in the Government’s financing targets or its market access parameters), these 
will be done on a consensus basis with the Government and other development partners. The 
revisions to the parameters will be guided by, but not limited to, the following considerations: 
(i) inflation rate, (ii) increased cost of bonds with longer maturities, (iii) bond maturities structure 
and volume consistent with past practice and prudent debt management, and (iv) possible 
crowding effects on the private sector.

FISCAL STIMULUS PACKAGES—INTERNATIONAL EXPERIENCE 
 
1.  This  appendix  summarizes  the  determinants  of  the  size  and  composition  of  fiscal 
stimulus packages and draws on the findings a number of recent International Monetary Fund 
(IMF) cross-country studies.1 Two sets of factors help explain the relative size of stimulus 
packages: (i) differences across countries in the need for stimulus, and (ii) differences in fiscal 
space. 
 
2.  Need  for  stimulus.  The  magnitude  of  the  overall  fiscal  expansion  (including  both 
discretionary and nondiscretionary components) should depend on the size of the output gap 
that each country faces in the absence of fiscal support. The fiscal expansion in a particular 
country should also be larger if multipliers are lower.   
 
3.  Composition of stimulus. Fiscal stimulus packages are typically comprised of (i) tax-
related measures, (ii) social sector spending, and (iii) infrastructure expenditures. However, the 
weight given to any one of these components depends on preexisting fiscal characteristics. 
Countries in which the automatic stabilizers are smaller (e.g., those that have less extensive 
social benefits programs) will require greater discretionary stimulus—this is true of most of the 
countries  in  Asia  in  relation  to  developed  economies.  Tax  stimulus  measures  can  be 
implemented relatively quickly and their impact is already being felt in the fiscal accounts. 
Expenditure measures, however, tend to proceed more slowly, reflecting normal budgetary 
controls and typical start-up delays in new programs. Multipliers, however, tend to be higher for 
expenditure-related stimulus measures than for tax-related ones. A recent IMF paper suggests 
that in a global recession fiscal multipliers for an individual economy will be higher if other 
countries operate fiscal stimulus programs through spillovers to imports, than if an individual 
country operates a fiscal expansion in isolation.2 The fiscal multipliers are larger if monetary 
policy is also accommodative.  
 
4.  Differences in fiscal space. Key factors that determine a country’s fiscal space to 
expand include levels of deficits, public debt, contingent liabilities, and interest rates. Countries 
facing relatively higher real interest rates or elevated debt levels have less room to expand; 
competing crisis-related needs, such as that for financial sector support (mainly in the US and 
Europe), are also factors in determining available fiscal space. 
 
5.  Increasing  fiscal  space.  The  available  fiscal  space  can  be  increased  through 
appropriate policy design. Ideally, a larger fiscal expansion in times of economic crisis can be 
accommodated if policy design increases the likelihood of a fiscal tightening once conditions 
improve, to ensure long-term fiscal solvency. In this respect, the IMF has offered a number of 
recommendations: 
 
(i)  Stimulus packages should not have permanent effects on deficits. Table A9.1 
provides  a  cross-country  comparison  of  stimulus  packages  in  terms  of  the 
permanent or temporary nature of their fiscal impact. 
(ii)  Medium-term fiscal frameworks should clarify the Government’s commitment to 
fiscal correction once economic conditions improve.
